title: England 19-7 New Zealand: Brilliant England turn rugby 'gods' into mere mortals
text:

Owen Farrell and his England heroes stormed into the final of the Rugby World Cup - then promised the best is still to come.

An astonishing mix of power, pace and precision allied to suffocating defence saw England crush the two-time defending champions in Yokohama.

Never had the Red Rose nation beaten New Zealand in a World Cup before ransacking their hopes and turning their dreams to nightmares yesterday.

“New Zealand are the gods of rugby,” Eddie Jones said after his side led from start to finish to set up a final against either Wales or South Africa this coming Saturday.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

“We wanted to take it to them, to put them on the back foot. Where this ranks as a performance we don’t know, we’re not historians.

“What we do know is that we can play better next week.”

England had the All Blacks on the back foot from the moment they lined up in V-formation and closed in on them during the pre-match haka.

(Image: PA)

“We wanted to make sure they understood we would be ready for the fight,” said Mako Vunipola.

Referee Nigel Owens actually had to warn Joe Marler to move back in order that the men in black could perform the famous Maori war-dance.

“Hope they don’t live to regret that,” World Cup winner Matt Dawson said from the sidelines, saying what England fans were doubtless thinking.

(Image: REUTERS)

He need not have worried. Not on this day, in this town, with this team, for England were simply sensational.

If New Zealand came into the contest as gods they left as mere mortals, so bruised that coach Steve Hansen appeared to offer out a journalist who questioned whether his players had turned up with the right attitude.

Condemning what he saw as disrespect, Hansen snapped: “If you want to spend some time outside I’ll give you a rugby education on that one.”

(Image: Getty Images)

(Image: REUTERS)

The mood in the England camp could not have been more different after a game which started with a bang - Manu Tuilagi scoring in just 98 seconds.

By half-time England led 10-0, only the second time this century New Zealand had reached the break scoreless.

And despite tries by Sam Underhill and Ben Youngs being chalked off they were so far the better side that New Zealand were resigned to the end of their 18-match, 12-year unbeaten run at the World Cup quite some time before the final whistle confirmed it.

(Image: Getty Images)

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

"We stepped up to the plate today,” said Hansen. “We played as well as we possibly could. We just got beaten by a better team. The team that took the game won the game. We have to take that on the chin.”

England had giants all over the park, none more so than man of the match Maro Itoje, who won three turnovers and seven lineouts.

Underhill and Tom Curry, the back row flanker duo Jones calls his ‘Kamikaze Kids’ were also revelations as England finished the game with 16 turnovers, the most by any side at this tournament.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

“You remember the meeting four years ago at Pennyhill Park, our first meeting together,” said Jones, as bookies installed his rampant side as odds-on favourites to become champions again. “We said we wanted to be the best team in the world.

“We're not the best team in the world but we've now got an opportunity to play in a game where we can prove we are.”

ENGLAND - Try: Tuilagi. Con: Farrell. Pen: Ford 4.

NEW ZEALAND - Try: Savea. Con: Mo’unga.
description: Eddie Jones' men produce greatest ever Rugby World Cup display by an England team to set up final against either Wales or South Africa
